awd_titl_txt: Mathematical Modeling of Antiretroviral Therapy in Pursuit of HIV Prevention and Cure
awd_abstract_narration:
There is currently no known cure or effective vaccine for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. In the absence of a vaccine, the most effective strategy for preventing HIV transmission is to implement the “treatment as prevention” approach, that is, antiretroviral medication to achieve undetectable viral load in patients, thereby preventing sexual transmission. For treatment and cure of HIV infection, one of the viable options is to begin therapy early in infection before the establishment of virus reservoirs such as latent infected CD4+ T cells and infected brain cells. This project develops and uses mathematical models of cell-virus interactions and computational methods to study the effectiveness of early antiretroviral therapy (ART), including a recently developed nanoparticle-based preventive therapy (NBPT), for treatment of HIV. The study will focus on HIV infections in three critical sites: vaginal mucosa, circulation, and brain. In addition to improving our current knowledge of HIV transmission dynamics, pathogenesis, and nanomedicine, this research will have a significant positive and practical impact on the development of therapies and vaccines for the control of HIV.

This project aims to generate novel nonautonomous systems of differential equations to study the effects of ART pharmacodynamics on the spatiotemporal distribution of HIV virus in vaginal mucosa and on the persistence of HIV in the virus reservoirs. The project will utilize experimental data from HIV infected humans and SIV (Simian Immunodeficiency Virus) infected macaques, as well as data from experiments on effectiveness of ARTs and NBPTs, for the model validation and the parameter estimation. The developed models will be extensively analyzed using dynamical systems theory as well as statistical, numerical, and machine learning methods. Mathematical and computational challenges anticipated in this research will offer opportunities to develop innovative techniques that advance the field of applied non-autonomous complex differential equations as well as optimal control theory. This project will also broaden the application of differential equation modeling to a machine learning framework. The results, including optimal treatment protocols, are intended help to inform evidence-based guidelines for managing, preventing, and curing HIV infection via early ARTs and NBPTs, thereby enhancing the quality of life for HIV infected patients. In addition, this project will provide extensive interdisciplinary research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There is currently no known cure or effective vaccine for human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. Therefore, for HIV prevention and cure, the viable option is to begin antiretroviral therapy (ART) pre- or immediate post-infection of the virus before the establishment of virus reservoirs, mainly the latent proviral DNA within resting CD4+ T cells and infected brain cells, which are an obstacle to cure. This project has developed novel mathematical models and computational methods to study the effectiveness of early antiretroviral therapy (ART), including nanoparticle-based preventive therapy (NBPT), for HIV prevention and cure. Specifically, the developed models and methods were implemented to evaluate the influence of early ART and NBPT on HIV infection in three critical sites: vaginal mucosa, circulation, and brain. Models resulting from the complex phenomena, such as pharmacodynamics of ART and NBPT, selection through the blood-brain barrier, spatial heterogeneity, and stochastic effects, dealt with in this project have significantly advanced the field of within-host disease modeling. These complex models, validated by experimental data from HIV-infected humans, SIV (Simian Immunodeficiency Virus) infected macaques, and laboratory tests of ARTs and NBPTs, have allowed us to develop mathematical theories related to dynamical systems, bifurcation analysis, asymptotic analysis, periodic systems, stability and persistence, and statistical and numerical methods that have advanced the field of applied differential equations and optimal control theory.

In addition to improving our current knowledge of HIV dynamics, pathogenesis, and nanomedicine, the results generated in this research may have a significant positive and practical impact on developing therapies and vaccines for HIV prevention and cure, helping healthcare professionals to mitigate burdens from HIV infection, thereby, providing the quality of life to HIV infected patients and their families. In addition, this project offered extensive interdisciplinary research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, including minority groups (Women, Hispanic, African American). The research conducted by students related to this project has produced two Ph.D. dissertations, three master's theses, and five undergraduate projects. The modeling techniques developed in this project have been incorporated into an interdisciplinary courses, "Mathematical Biology and Biomedicine" and "Mathematical Modeling," offered at San Diego State University. In addition, the modeling techniques and results were also presented as teaching materials to students during the "Summer School in Data Visualization, Modeling, and Mathematical Tools" organized at Tribhuvan University of Nepal and the "Summer School in Infectious Disease Modeling" at National Taiwan University, Taiwan. The modeling techniques developed in this project were also successfully applied to other diseases, such as COVID-19, Influenza, Hepatitis B, Dengue, Malaria, Zika, Lyme, and Rabies. Results from this project have been disseminated through peer-reviewed publications in scientific journals and presentations at scientific national and international meetings.
